title: Reporter’s Phablet: Growing Web of Corporate Connections Creates Opportunity, Risk
text:
NEW YORK—Companies are struggling to manage risk tied to their digitally connected networks of contractors and subcontractors, business partners, gig workers and far-flung global customers.

“No one and everyone is in charge and it is a bit of a blessing and a curse,” said Dan Kinsella, a partner with Deloitte Risk and Financial Advisory, part of Deloitte LLP. He refers to his specialty as the “extended enterprise,” the network of third parties connected to the formal structure of the corporation itself.

This extended enterprise has grown out of necessity, as corporations look to drive down costs and race against rivals to take advantage of the latest mapping service or payment platform on the market, he said.

The result, he said in an interview at The Wall Street Journal’s headquarters, is a business structure that poses a unique set of opportunities and risks.

Mr. Kinsella, based in Omaha, Neb., was in town to talk about Deloitte’s fourth extended-enterprise risk-management survey, a global, cross-industry study of 1,055 corporations. Highlights of the conversation:

•The number of elements in the extended enterprise and the volume of activity flowing through them rose about 15% during the past year, according to Mr. Kinsella. The increase was calculated by multiplying the number of connections in these networks by the volume of activity, Mr. Kinsella said.

•During the past three years, 83% of corporations have experienced a problematic incident related to a third party, and half of survey respondents indicated they don’t understand the nature of their third-party relationships.

•Only 1% of corporations said they considered themselves fully prepared to address all important issues related to extended enterprise risk management.

Companies can improve management of their extended enterprise, even to the point of boosting the bottom line, Mr. Kinsella contends. How so? The first step is to make sure senior leadership and the board itself are aware of the risks associated with the extended enterprise, and monitor them.

Step two, he said, is technology. Companies can buy software platforms for managing their extended enterprise, and deploy more specialized applications within that framework. They also have the option of outsourcing management of third-party risk to yet another third party, a company such as Deloitte.

The API

“There is a fundamental shift in the way that innovation happens. It’s no longer done within the four walls of your organization. It’s actually done through ecosystems,” Ross Mason, founder of MuleSoft LLC, said last week at a customer event. MuleSoft, acquired last year by Salesforce.com Inc. for $6.5 billion, helps companies create and manage the pieces of software that enable applications, data and devices to connect to one another.

MuleSoft founder Ross Mason speaking in New York City, Sept. 17, 2019 Photo: Steven Rosenbush / The Wall Street Journal

This connective tissue, known as the application programming interface, makes it possible for a phone to connect to an app store, or for a restaurant reservation app to mark dinner plans on your calendar.

It also helps corporations integrate third parties into their own businesses. He calls this the “broader village.”

“Uber didn’t build a payment broker. They used Stripe…They didn’t build telephony…What they did is build in telephony into the application using Twilio , ” Mr. Mason said. “The value of Uber isn’t measured by whether they built maps or telephony. It’s actually measured by the value they provide to consumers.”

Third-Party Robots

“I think that working with a company like VirtualAPT gives us access to technologists that we probably wouldn’t have in a construction company,” said Anthony Colonna, senior vice president for innovative construction solutions at Skanska USA Building Inc., part of multinational Skanska Group.

Bryan Colin, VirtualAPT, left, and Anthony Colonna, Skanska Photo: Steven Rosenbush / The Wall Street Journal

He applies advanced technology to projects such as the redevelopment of LaGuardia Airport and Penn Station in New York. That includes building relationships with startups such as Brooklyn, N.Y.-based VirtualAPT, which uses autonomous robots to capture video.

Those relationships work best when everyone benefits, Mr. Colonna told the Journal last week during a Skanska technology showcase. “This is the first construction thing we have ever done,” said Bryan Colin, co-founder and CEO of VirtualAPT, which has its roots in advertising and marketing. “Tony said we can use this…in an industry we never would have set foot in.”

—Tom Loftus contributed to this article
